fr.sorbonne_u.components.hem2025e3.equipments.meter

Class ElectricMeterCyPhy

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.components.AbstractComponent
      • fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.AbstractCyPhyComponent
        • fr.sorbonne_u.components.hem2025e3.equipments.meter.ElectricMeterCyPhy
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    fr.sorbonne_u.components.ComponentI, fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.interfaces.CyPhyComponentI, ElectricMeterImplementationI

    public class ElectricMeterCyPhy
extends fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.AbstractCyPhyComponent
implements ElectricMeterImplementationI
    The class ElectricMeter implements a simplified electric meter component.

    Description

    The electric meter gathers the electric power consumption of all appliances and the electric power production of all production units to provide these metrics to the household energy manager.

    This implementation of the electric meter provides two possible execution modes:

    1. STANDARD means that the component would execute in normal operational conditions, on the field (which is not used in this project but would be in an industrial project).
    2. UNIT_TEST means that the component executes in unit tests where it is the sole appliance but cooperates with the HairDryerUser component.
    3. INTEGRATION_TEST means that the component executes in integration tests where other appliances coexist and where it must cooperates with the HairDryerUser and also the ElectricMeter components.

    There are also four distinct types of simulations defined by SimulationType:

    1. NO_SIMULATION means that the component does not execute a simulator, a type necessarily used in STANDARD executions but also for UNIT_TEST with no simulation.
    2. MIL_SIMULATION means that only MIL simulators will run; it is meant to be used early stages of a project in UNIT_TEST and INTEGRATION_TEST before implementing the code of the components.
    3. MIL_RT_SIMULATION is similar to MIL_SIMULATION but simulates in real time or an accelerated real time; it is more a step towards SIL simulations than an actual interesting simulation type in an industrial project.
    4. SIL_SIMULATION means that the simulators are implemented so that they can execute with the component software in software-in-the-loop simulations; it can be used in UNIT_TEST executions to test the component software in isolation and then in INTEGRATION_TEST executions to test the entire application at once.

    In this implementation of the ElectricMeter component, the standard execution type is not really implemented as the software is not embedded in any real appliances. Unit tests are relatively meaningless for the ElectricMeter component as it is only useful when appliances and production units are present in the execution. In integration tests with no simulation, the component is totally passive as its methods are called by the HEM component. In MIL, MIL real time and SIL simulations, the component simply creates and installs its local simulation architecture, which execution will be started by a supervisor component.

    For SIL simulations in integration tests, the ElectricMeter component creates the following local component simulation architecture:

    Every electricity model of every appliance and production unit will have to added to the local SIL simulation architecture of the ElectricMeter, which will therefore also receive all of the relevant events coming from the local architectures of the appliances and production unit to propagate them to the appropriate electricity models.

    Implementation Invariants

     invariant       currentPowerConsumption.get() == null || currentPowerConsumption.get().getMeasure().getData() >= 0.0 && currentPowerConsumption.get().getMeasure().getMeasurementUnit().equals(POWER_UNIT)
 invariant       currentPowerProduction.get() == null || currentPowerProduction.get().getMeasure().getData() >= 0.0 && currentPowerProduction.get().getMeasure().getMeasurementUnit().equals(POWER_UNIT)
 invariant       !getExecutionMode().isSimulationTest() || (localArchitectureURI != null && !localArchitectureURI.isEmpty())
 invariant       !getExecutionMode().isSimulationTest() || accFactor > 0.0

    Invariant

     invariant       REFLECTION_INBOUND_PORT_URI != null && !REFLECTION_INBOUND_PORT_URI.isEmpty()
 invariant       ELECTRIC_METER_INBOUND_PORT_URI != null && !ELECTRIC_METER_INBOUND_PORT_URI.isEmpty()
 invariant       TENSION != null
 invariant       TENSION.getData() > 0.0
 invariant       TENSION.getMeasurementUnit().equals(TENSION_UNIT)
 invariant       X_RELATIVE_POSITION >= 0
 invariant       Y_RELATIVE_POSITION >= 0
 invariant       NUMBER_OF_STANDARD_THREADS >= 0
 invariant       NUMBER_OF_SCHEDULABLE_THREADS >= 0

         pre     getExecutionMode().isSimulationTest()

 pre     t != null
 post    true        // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        power - electric power consumption in POWER_UNIT.
        t - simulated time at which the power has been measured.

      • setCurrentPowerProduction

        public void setCurrentPowerProduction(double power,
                                      fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.models.time.Time t)
        set the current power consumption, a method that is meant to be called only by the simulator in SIL runs, otherwise a hardware sensor would be used in standard executions.

        Contract

         pre     getExecutionMode().isSimulationTest()
 pre     power >= 0.0
 pre     t != null
 post    true        // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        power - electric power consumption in POWER_UNIT.
        t - simulated time at which the power has been measured.
